{{pp-30-500|small=yes}} {{About|the 2010 flotilla|the 2010 flotilla raid and its aftermath|Gaza flotilla raid|the 2011 flotilla|Freedom Flotilla II|the 2015 flotilla|Freedom Flotilla III}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} {{Coord|32.64113|33.56727|type:event_region:XZ|display=title}} {{Gaza blockade}} The '''Gaza Freedom Flotilla''', organized by the [[Free Gaza Movement]] and the Turkish [[IHH (Turkish NGO)|Foundation for Human Rights and Freedoms and Humanitarian Relief]] (İHH), was carrying humanitarian aid and construction materials, with the intention of breaking the Israeli-Egyptian [[Blockade of the Gaza Strip (2007-present)|blockade of the Gaza Strip]].{{Cite news|last1=Buck|first1=Tobias|last2=Dombey|first2=Daniel|last3=Strauss|first3=Delphine|journal=Financial Times|title=Israel condemned after flotilla attack|date=31 May 2010|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/b09c57f6-6c80-11df-91c8-00144feab49a.html?ftcamp=rss|accessdate=24 June 2010}}{{Cite news |first=Ian |last=Black |date=31 May 2010 |author2=Haroon Siddique |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/may/31/q-a-gaza-freedom-flotilla |title=Q&A: The Gaza Freedom flotilla |work=The Guardian | location=London |accessdate=2 June 2010}} In normal circumstances, aid is brought to Israel to be inspected and then transferred to Gaza.{{cite news|last1=Ravid|first1=Barak|title=Israel: Gaza aid convoy can unload cargo in Ashdod for inspection|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/israel-gaza-aid-convoy-can-unload-cargo-in-ashdod-for-inspection-1.292560|accessdate=13 July 2014|publisher=Haaretz|date=27 May 2010}} On 31 May 2010, Israeli forces [[Gaza flotilla raid|boarded the ships]] from speedboats and helicopters. Following resistance on one of the boats, nine activists were killed by Israeli forces. Widespread [[Reactions to the Gaza flotilla raid|international condemnation of and reaction to]] the raid followed, [[Israel–Turkey relations]] were strained, and Israel subsequently eased its blockade on the Gaza Strip. ==Overview== The flotilla was the Free Gaza Movement's ninth attempt to break the [[2007-present blockade of the Gaza Strip#Naval blockade|naval blockade]] imposed by Israel on the [[Gaza Strip]].{{cite news |last=Foulkes |first=Imogen |date=14 June 2010 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10306193 |title=ICRC says Israel's Gaza blockade breaks law |work=BBC News |accessdate=3 October 2011 }}
• {{Cite news |date=14 August 2009 |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,539363,00.html |title=U.N. Human Rights Chief: Israel's Blockade of Gaza Strip Is Illegal |work=Fox News |accessdate=3 October 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111020193536/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,539363,00.html# |archive-date=20 October 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Israel proposed inspecting the [[cargo]] at the [[Port of Ashdod]] and then delivering [[Goods allowed/banned for import into Gaza|non-blockaded goods]] through land crossings, but this proposal was turned down. Israeli forces then [[Gaza flotilla raid|raided and seized]] the [[Port of Gaza|Gaza-bound]] ships in [[international waters]] of the [[Mediterranean Sea]]. Five shipments had been allowed through prior to the [[Gaza War (2008–09)|2008–09 Gaza War]], but all shipments following the war were blocked by Israel.{{Cite news |last=Demirjian |first=Karoun |date=28 May 2010 |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2011964191_apmlisraelshipstogaza.html |title=Israeli commandos to block Gaza activists |work=The Seattle Times |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=3 October 2011}} This flotilla was the largest to date. An Islamic aid group from Turkey, the [[İHH (İnsani Yardım Vakfı)]] (Foundation for Human Rights and Freedoms and Humanitarian Relief) sponsored a large passenger ship and two cargo ships. While the UN's official report found Israel's blockade of Gaza to be legal,{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/02/world/middleeast/02flotilla.html |title=Report Finds Naval Blockade by Israel Legal but Faults Raid |work=The New York Times |date=2 September 2011 |first1=Neil |last1=MacFarquhar |first2=Ethan |last2=Bronner}}{{cite news |url=http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=236369 |title= Palmer report: Gaza blockade legal, IDF force excessive}} another set of UN experts, reporting to the [[Human Rights Council]], came to the opposite conclusion finding that it violated international law.{{cite news|title=U.N. experts say Israel's blockade of Gaza illegal|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/09/13/us-un-gaza-rights-idUSTRE78C59R20110913|accessdate=2013-05-05|newspaper=Reuters|date=Sep 13, 2011}} ==Organization== ===Ships=== The ships of the Gaza flotilla raid comprised three passenger ships and three cargo ships: * ''Challenger 1'' (small yacht), [[United States|US]], Free Gaza Movement * MS ''Eleftheri Mesogios (Free Mediterranean)'' or ''Sofia'' (cargo boat), [[Greece]], [[Sweden]] {{Sfn|UNHRC report|2010|p=20}} Greek Ship to Gaza * ''Sfendoni''(small passenger boat), Greece Greek Ship to Gaza and European Campaign to End the Siege on Gaza * MV ''Mavi Marmara'' (passenger ship), [[Comoros]], İHH * ''Gazze'', [[Turkey]], İHH * ''Defne Y'', [[Kiribati]], İHH Two other Free Gaza Movement ships, ''Challenger 2'' (USA flagged) and MV [[MV Rachel Corrie|''Rachel Corrie'']] ([[Cambodia]] flagged) were behind the rest of the flotilla due to mechanical problems. There have been claims this was due to Israeli sabotage.{{Cite news|last=Lis|first=Jonathan|journal=Haaretz|title=Mossad chief: Israel gradually becoming burden on U.S.|date=1 June 2010|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/mossad-chief-israel-gradually-becoming-burden-on-u-s-1.293540|accessdate=5 June 2010}}
• {{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/7802608/Gaza-flotilla-Israel-accused-of-sabotaging-Irish-aid-ship-Rachel-Corrie.html |title=Gaza flotilla: Israel accused of 'sabotaging' Irish aid ship ''Rachel Corrie'' |work=Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=4 June 2010 |accessdate=25 June 2011}}
• {{Cite news|last1=Booth |first1=Robert |last2=Black |first2=Ian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jun/01/israel-gaza-flotilla-sabotage-suspected |title=Gaza aid flotilla: Israeli sabotage suspected |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=1 June 2010 |accessdate=26 June 2010}} ''Challenger 2'' aborted,{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} but the [[Gaza journey of MV Rachel Corrie|''Rachel Corrie'' continued its journey]].{{Cite web |title=Taoiseach warns Israel of 'consequences' over arrests |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0601/breaking33.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605134156/http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0601/breaking33.html |work=Irish Times |date=1 June 2010 |archivedate=5 June 2010 |accessdate=13 June 2011 |quote=MV ''Rachel Corrie'' ... is ploughing ahead with its attempt to deliver aid to Gaza despite yesterday's deadly attack by the Israeli navy on a Gaza-bound flotilla.}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! [[Ship flag|Flag]] !! [[Ship prefix|Name]] !! Organisation !! [[Port State Control|Port]] !! Passengers !! Crew !! class="unsortable" | Cargo |- | {{flagicon|USA}} [[United States|USA]] || ''Challenger 1'' || [[Free Gaza Movement]] || [[Heraklion]] || || || |- | {{flagicon|USA}} [[United States|USA]] || ''Challenger 2'' || [[Free Gaza Movement]] || [[Heraklion]] || || || |- | {{flagicon|Greece}} [[Greece]] || [[Motor ship|MS]] ''Eleftheri Mesogeios'' || Greek Ship to Gaza || [[Piraeus]] || || || Wheelchairs, building materials, medicine{{cite news |date=2 June 2010 |url=http://www.kuwaittimes.net/read_news.php?newsid=NjExOTg4MDAz |title=Freed activists recount bullets, electroshocks |work=Kuwait Times |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110617020512/http://www.kuwaittimes.net/read_news.php?newsid=NjExOTg4MDAz |archivedate=17 June 2011 |accessdate=3 October 2011}} |- | {{flagicon|Greece}} [[Greece]] || ''Sfendoni'' || Greek Ship to Gaza,
European Campaign to End the Siege on Gaza || [[Piraeus]] || || |- | {{flagicon|Comoros}} [[Comoros]] || MV ''[[Mavi Marmara]]'' || [[IHH (İnsani Yardım Vakfı)|IHH]] || [[Antalya]] || 581 || || |- | {{flagicon|Turkey}} [[Turkey]] || ''Gazze'' || [[IHH (İnsani Yardım Vakfı)|IHH]] || [[Antalya]] || 5 || 13 || 2,104 tons of cement, 600 tons of construction steel, and 50 tons of tiles{{cite news |date=28 May 2010 |url=http://www.aksam.com.tr/2010/05/28/haber/dunya/5319/ozgurluk_filosu_nu_komandolar_basacak.html |title=Özgürlük Filosu'nu komandolar basacak |trans-title=Commandos will board Liberty Fleet |language=Turkish |location=Istanbul |work=Aksam |accessdate=3 October 2011 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} |- | {{flagicon|Kiribati}} [[Kiribati]] || ''MV Defne Y'' || [[IHH (İnsani Yardım Vakfı)|IHH]] || [[Antalya]] || 27 || 23 || 150 tons of iron, 98 power units, 50 precast homes, 16 units of children's playground equipment, food, shoes, medicine, wheelchairs, clothing items, notebooks and textbooks{{cite news |last=Mohyeldin |first=Ayman |url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2010/06/01/evidence-belies-israeli-claim |title=Evidence belies Israeli claim |work=Al Jazeera |date=1 June 2010 |accessdate=12 June 2010}} |- | {{flagicon|Cambodia}} [[Cambodia]] || MV ''[[MV Rachel Corrie|Rachel Corrie]]'' || [[Free Gaza Movement]] || [[Dundalk]] || 11 || 8 || 550 tons of cement, 20 tons of paper, 100 tons of high-end medical equipment, wheelchairs, books, fabric, and thread |} ===Cargo=== Three of the flotilla ships carried only passengers and their personal belongings, while three other ships carried 10,000 tons of humanitarian aid, with an estimated value of $20 million. The cargo included food, wheelchairs, books, toys, electricity generators, operating theater equipment, medicines,{{Cite news |last=Sherwood |first=Harriet |date=25 May 2010 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/may/25/gaza-flotilla-aid-attempt |title=Gaza aid flotilla to set sail for confrontation with Israel |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=3 October 2011}}
• {{Cite news |date=28 May 2010 |author=王寒露 (Wáng Hánlù) |url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90854/7004513.html |title=Turkish aid ship leaves for Gaza |location=Beijing |work=People's Daily Online |accessdate=3 October 2011}} medical equipment, textiles, footwear, cash, [[mobility scooter]]s, [[Couch|sofas]], and building materials, such as cement, which are [[2007–present blockade of the Gaza Strip#Goods blocked|prohibited under the Israeli blockade]], although Israel offered to allow the cement to enter Gaza, if the flotilla were to dock in Ashdod.{{cite web|date=5 June 2010 |url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Government/Communiques/2010/7th_flotilla_ship_ignores_Israel_Navy_dock_Ashdod_5-Jun-2010.htm |title=Ship attempting to break Gaza maritime closure boarded without incident |publisher=Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sWOitnmI?url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Government/Communiques/2010/7th_flotilla_ship_ignores_Israel_Navy_dock_Ashdod_5-Jun-2010.htm |archivedate=5 September 2010 |deadurl=no |accessdate=3 October 2011 |df=dmy }} [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Combat Gear Found Aboard the Mavi Marmara (1).jpg|thumb|Night vision binoculars found on the deck of the Mavi Marmara, along with a scope to be mounted on a sniper rifle.]] [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Weaponry Used by Passengers Aboard the Mavi Marmara (2).jpg|thumb|Knives, wrenches, and wooden clubs used to attack the soldiers during the flotilla raid.]] [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Combat Gear Found Aboard the Mavi Marmara.jpg|thumb|Bulletproof vests found on the deck of the Marmara.]] Israeli news reported the flotilla to be carrying [[ballistic vest]]s, [[gas mask]]s, [[night-vision goggles]], [[Club (weapon)|club]]s, and [[slingshot]]s, although the UNHRC report does not mention these items{{Sfn|UNHRC report|2010|pp=22–24}} and in the Turkish Report on the Israeli attack on the Humanitarian Aid Convoy to Gaza it states that all passengers and crew as well as the cargo were searched to international standards and no weapons were found, on the ships departing from Turkey. {{Harvnb|Turkish NCI interim report|2010|p=10}}: "All personal belongings and cargo were also thoroughly inspected and cleared."
• {{Harvnb|Turkish NCI final report|2011|p=113}}. [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Expired Medicine Unloaded Off Gaza Flotillas (3).jpg|thumb|Seen here are many boxes of expired medicine which were to be delivered as aid by the Gaza flotilla.]] Two-thirds of the medicines delivered by the flotilla expired between six and fifteen months prior to the raid,{{Cite news|date=8 June 2010 |title=Hamas prevents flotilla aid from entering Gaza |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/hamas-prevents-flotilla-aid-from-entering-gaza-1.294938 |work=Haaretz |agency=DPA |archivedate=5 September 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sVxW9ZkI?url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/hamas-prevents-flotilla-aid-from-entering-gaza-1.294938 |deadurl=no |accessdate=3 October 2011 |df=dmy }} and were found to be useless. Some other medicines found on the flotilla were due to expire soon. Additionally, Israel said that much of the cargo, including sensitive medical equipment, was found to have been scattered in the ship's holds, and put in piles rather than packed properly for transport, and consequently damaged. Operating theater equipment, which was supposed to be kept sterile, was carelessly wrapped. The expiring medications and sensitive equipment were kept in frozen storage in the Israeli Defense Ministry before delivery to Gaza.{{cite news |last=Ronen |first=Gil |date=10 June 2010 |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/news.aspx/137997 |title=It's Official: There was No Humanitarian Aid on Mavi Marmara |work=Israel National News |accessdate=3 October 2011}} ===Passengers=== {{Main|List of participants of the Gaza flotilla}} In previous voyages, Free Gaza vessels carried 140 passengers in total. In this flotilla, over 600 activists were on board the Mavi Marmara alone. There were 663 passengers from 37 nations on board the flotilla. Notable people aboard the flotilla included former UN Assistant Secretary-General Denis Halliday, former [[U.S. Ambassador to Mauritania]] Edward Peck, and {{USS|Liberty|AGTR-5|6}} survivor Joe Meadors.{{cite news |last=Sugden |first=Joanna |date=1 June 2010 |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article7141720.ece |title=Gaza ships: the passenger list |location=London |work=The Times |accessdate=3 October 2011}} Israeli-Arab member of [[Knesset]] [[Haneen Zoubi]], leader of the northern branch of the [[Islamic Movement in Israel]] [[Raed Salah]], Swedish novelist [[Henning Mankell]], convicted hijacker [[Erdinç Tekir]], who participated in the [[Black Sea hostage crisis|Black Sea hijacking]],{{cite news |date=20 August 2011 |url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/n.php?n=turkish-press-scan-for-aug.-20-2010-08-20 |title=Turkish Press Scan for Aug. 20: Two Ships, Same Activist |work=Hürriyet Daily News |accessdate=3 October 2011}} and a number of parliamentarians from European and Arab national legislatures and the [[European Parliament]].{{Cite news |last=McGeough |first=Paul |date=31 May 2010 |url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/tension-builds-as-flotilla-approaches-gaza-20100530-wnjb.html |title=Tension builds as flotilla approaches Gaza |work=Sydney Morning Herald |accessdate=8 June 2010}} ====Ties with groups marked as terror organizations==== In Jun 2010 Assistant Secretary of State P.J. Crowley told reporters Wednesday: "'We know that IHH representatives have met with senior Hamas officials in Turkey, Syria and Gaza over the past three years,'" and "'That is obviously of great concern to us.'"{{Cite news |last=Krieger |first=Hilary |date=3 June 2010 |url=http://www.jpost.com/International/US-concerned-over-IHH-Hamas-ties |title=US concerned over IHH-Hamas ties |work=Jerusalem Post |accessdate=3 June 2010}} The AP was quoted on msnbc ''The Turkish Islamic charity behind a flotilla of aid ships that was raided by Israeli forces on its way to Gaza had ties to terrorism networks, including a 1999 al-Qaida plot to bomb Los Angeles International Airport, France's former top anti-terrorism judge said Wednesday.''{{Cite news |last=de Montesquiou |first=Alfred |date=2 June 2010 |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/37477182/ns/world_news-europe/t/turkish-aid-group-had-terror-ties/ |title=Turkish aid group had terror ties |work=NBC News |accessdate=2 June 2010}} In Jun 2012 it was reported that the IHH director [[Fehmi Bülent Yıldırım]] is reportedly being investigated by Turkish authorities for allegedly creating a financial partnership with al-Qaeda.{{Cite news |date=17 July 2012 |url=http://www.terrorism-info.org.il/Data/articles/Art_20359/E_128_12_1881078791.pdf |work=Intelligence and Terrorism Information Center |title=According to the Turkish media (June 2012), IHH head Bülent Yildirim was under investigation for having clandestinely transferred funds to Al-Qaeda.}} ==Motives== {{Undue weight section|date=May 2013}} [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Passengers Use Violence on the Mavi Marmara.jpg|thumb|In a still taken from video footage filmed on the deck of the ship, activists on the Mavi Marmara throw a stun grenade at Israeli Navy commando soldiers.]] Israel questioned the humanitarian motives of flotilla organizers. Israel said it had invited the organizers to use the land crossings but they were "less interested in bringing in aid than in promoting their radical agenda, playing into the hands of Hamas provocations. While they have wrapped themselves in a humanitarian cloak, they are engaging in political propaganda and not in pro-Palestinian aid."{{cite web |last=Palmor |first=Yigal |date=24 May 2010 |url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/HumanitarianAid/Palestinians/MFA_Spokesman_Gaza_flotilla_24-May-2010.htm |publisher=Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs |title=MFA Spokesman on Gaza flotilla |accessdate=3 October 2011}} [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Mavi Marmara Activists Prepare to Attack IDF Soldiers (1).jpg|thumb|Footage taken from the Mavi Marmara security cameras shows the activists preparing to attack IDF soldiers.]] According to an early IDF press release, the ship carried 75 [[mercenaries]] with links to [[al-Qaeda]] and other [[List of designated terrorist organizations|terror organizations]], who carried $10,000 apiece on their persons,{{Cite web|last=Benhorin |first=Yitzhak |date=13 June 2010 |title=Ayalon to CNN: We won't apologize for flotilla raid |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3904526,00.html |work=Ynetnews |location=Tel Aviv |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sWA5vonm?url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3904526,00.html |archivedate=5 September 2010 |deadurl=no |accessdate=24 June 2011 |df=dmy }} The claim was never substantiated and was later withdrawn.{{cite news |last=Shabi |first=Rachel |date=6 June 2010 |title=Israel forced to apologise for YouTube spoof of Gaza flotilla |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jun/06/israel-youtube-gaza-flotilla |work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=1 July 2011}} Israel has said that the group boarded separately in a different city and went on deck under different procedures. The Turkish Customs officials and the İHH denied the allegations.{{cite web|last=Federman |first=Josef |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2010/jun/6/israel-says-activists-prepared-fight-ship/ |title=Israel says activists prepared for fight on ship |work=The Washington Times |date=6 June 2010 |accessdate=3 April 2011}} The impending arrival of the fleet was known to Israel government, military intelligence and press.{{cite news |date=28 May 2010 |title=Head to Head in the Heart of the Sea |work=Maariv |page=4}}{{cite web |last=Blumenthal |first=Max |date=3 June 2010 |url=http://maxblumenthal.com/2010/06/the-flotilla-raid-was-not-bungled-the-idf-detailed-its-violent-strategy-in-advance/ |title=The Flotilla Raid Was Not 'Bungled.' The IDF Detailed Its Violent Strategy In Advance |work=MaxBlumenthal.com |accessdate=8 June 2010}} Israel said that the flotilla was violating international law, but one of the flotilla's organizers, [[Greta Berlin]], stated that "[w]e have the right to sail from international waters into the waters of Gaza". Israel informed the fleet that it would be redirected to the port of [[Ashdod]]{{Cite news |last=Kershner |first=Isabel |date=27 May 2010 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/28/world/middleeast/28mideast.html?fta=y |title=Defying Blockade, Cargo and Passenger Vessels Head for Gaza |work=New York Times |accessdate=25 June 2010}} and the cargo would be transferred to Gaza after undergoing a security inspection.{{Cite news|author=Fox News |agency=NewsCore and AP |url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2010/05/30/reports-israeli-ships-attack-aid-flotilla-dead/ |title=Israeli Officials Claim Aid Flotilla Had Ties to Al Qaeda, PM Gives Military 'Full Support' |date=31 May 2010 |work=Fox News |archivedate=5 September 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sWSmQXhI?url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2010/05/30/reports-israeli-ships-attack-aid-flotilla-dead/ |deadurl=no |accessdate=25 June 2011 |df=dmy }} Foreigners would be deported or, if they did not willingly agree to be deported, detained. The flotilla organisers rejected Israel's demand, as it did not believe that Israel would transfer the cargo to Gaza, and said that, "This mission is not about delivering humanitarian supplies, it's about breaking Israel's siege on 1.5 million Palestinians...{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/05/2010528431964325.html |title=Tensions rise over Gaza aid fleet |work=Al Jazeera English |date=28 May 2010 |author=Al Jazeera and agencies |accessdate=25 June 2010}} We want to raise international awareness about the prison-like closure of Gaza and pressure the international community to review its sanctions policy and end its support for continued Israeli occupation." The [[United Nations Human Rights Council|UNHRC]] fact-finding mission noted a "certain tension between the political objectives of the flotilla and its humanitarian objectives", which came to light "the moment the Government of Israel made offers to allow the humanitarian aid to be delivered via Israeli ports but under the supervision of a neutral organization". It also announced that Gaza did not have a deep sea port capable of receiving the sort of cargo ships participating in the flotilla. It concluded that "whilst the mission is satisfied that the flotilla constituted a serious attempt to bring essential humanitarian supplies into Gaza, it seems clear that the primary objective was political, as indeed demonstrated by the decision of those on board the ''Rachel Corrie'' to reject a Government of [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]-sponsored proposal that the cargo in that ship be allowed through [[Ashdod]] intact".{{Sfn|UNHRC report|2010|p=19}} Some supporters of the flotilla said that "a violent response from Israel will breathe new life into the Palestine solidarity movement, drawing attention to the blockade."{{cite web |url=http://intifada-palestine.com/2010/05/gaza-freedom-march-prepares-emergency-response-for-freedom-flotilla/ |title=Gaza Freedom March Prepares Emergency Response for Freedom FLOTILLA |work=Intifada Palestine |date=28 May 2010 |accessdate=25 June 2011}}
• {{Cite news |work=New York Times: Editorial |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/02/opinion/02wed1.html |title=Israel and the Blockade |author=NY Times editors|date=1 June 2010|accessdate=4 June 2010}} Two of the activists (Ali Haydar Bengi and Ibrahim Bilgen) who died during the MV ''Mavi Marmara'' clash had previously said that they wished for martydom. On 29 May, Aljazeera broadcast footage of ''Mavi Marmara'' activists participating in a chant calling for battle against Jews.{{Cite news |last1=Marcus |first1=Itamar |last2=Zilberdik |first2=Nan Jacques |date=31 May 2010 |url=http://www.palwatch.org/main.aspx?fi=157&doc_id=2323 |title=Gaza flotilla participants created war atmosphere before confronting Israel |work=Palestinian Media Watch |accessdate=25 June 2011}} Former U.S. Marine [[Kenneth O'Keefe]], who was aboard the Mavi Marmara, stated that the activists knew from the outset that there would be no [[passive resistance]]. "I knew that if the Israelis boarded that ship, it would be a disaster...You have to be an idiot to board that ship and think it will be a ship of passive resistance," he told [[Haaretz]] newspaper.{{cite news |last=Sheizaf |first=Noam |date=24 September 2010 |url=http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/magazine/rough-passage-1.315481 |title=Rough Passage |work=Haaretz |accessdate=3 April 2011}} In a public address in October 2010 on ''Al-Aqsa TV'', Abd Al-Razzaq Al-Maqri, Head of Moroccan and Algerian Delegation to the Gaza Convoy, stated, according to a translation published by [[MEMRI]], that "the mujahideen have told us that they decided not to defeat the oppressive Jews by gunfire, but instead, by daggers."{{Cite web |url=http://www.memritv.org/clip_transcript/en/2682.htm |title=Abd Al-Razzaq Al-Maqri, Head of Moroccan and Algerian Delegation to Convoy to Gaza: 'Israel Will Be Annihilated Soon' |location=Washington, DC |publisher=MEMRI |id=Clip No. 2682 |date=22 October 2010 |accessdate=25 June 2011}} ==Initial leg== Six of the eight ships set out on 30 May 2010 from international waters off the coast of [[Cyprus]]; the remaining two were delayed by mechanical problems.{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/Content.aspx?id=110502|title=4 Turks dead on aid ship|work=Business Day|author=Foreign staff|date=1 June 2010|accessdate=3 June 2010}} "We do not even have a jackknife here, but we will not let Israeli soldiers on board this ship," İHH leader [[Fehmi Bülent Yıldırım]] told reporters via a live video stream before the convoy set sail. The government of Cyprus refused to cooperate with the Free Gaza Movement or allow activists to sail from its harbors. The [[Cyprus Police]] stated that "anything related to the trip to Gaza is not permitted," and as a result remaining MPs and activists embarked instead from [[Famagusta]] in [[Northern Cyprus]].{{cite web |last=Kambas |first=Michele |date=28 May 2010 |url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LDE64R19P.htm |title=Cyprus bans activists from joining flotilla |work=AlertNet |publisher=Thomson Reuters Foundation |accessdate=4 October 2011}}{{cite web |last=Psyllides |first=George |date=30 May 2010 |url=http://www.cyprus-mail.com/cyprus/flotilla-ready-set-sail/20100530 |title=Flotilla ready to set sail |work=Cyprus Mail |accessdate=3 June 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100601173149/http://www.cyprus-mail.com/cyprus/flotilla-ready-set-sail/20100530# |archive-date=1 June 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Cypriot and Greek MPs and activists refused to embark via ports in Northern Cyprus.{{cite web |last=Kourakis |first=T |date=29 May 2010 |title=Ευρωπαίοι ακτιβιστές έφυγαν από τα κατεχόμενα για τη Γάζα |trans-title=European activists have left for occupied Gaza |language=Greek |url=http://news.in.gr/greece/article/?aid=1231046788 |work=[[In.gr]] |accessdate=4 June 2010}} Having been delayed by two days, the flotilla aimed to reach Gaza on the afternoon of 31 May. ===Pre-raid sabotage rumors=== There are claims that the IDF or the [[Mossad]] may have sabotaged three of the ships before the raid. According to the [[National Post]], Israeli deputy defense minister [[Matan Vilnai]] hinted that Israel had exhausted covert means of stalling the vessels. He said: "Everything was considered. I don't want to elaborate beyond that, because the fact is there were not up to 10, or however many ships were [originally] planned."{{Cite news |last=Williams |first=Dan |date=1 June 2010 |title=Israel admits mistakes in boarding ship |url=https://nationalpost.com/news/world/Israel+admits+mistakes+boarding+ship/3100603/story.html#ixzz0sC6xcKZd |archive-url=https://archive.is/20100606055157/http://www.nationalpost.com/news/world/Israel+admits+mistakes+boarding+ship/3100603/story.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 June 2010 |work=National Post |agency=Reuters |accessdate=4 October 2011}} A senior IDF officer hinted to the [[Knesset]] Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee that some of the vessels had been tampered with to halt them far from the Gaza or Israeli coast.{{Cite news |last1=Macintyre |first1=Donald |last2=Green |first2=Toby |date=5 June 2010 |title=Israel warns Gaza-bound 'Rachel Corrie' to stop |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/israel-warns-gazabound-rachel-corrie-to-stop-1992079.html |work=The Independent |location=London|accessdate=28 June 2010}} According to UPI press coverage, the officer alluded to "grey operations" against the flotilla and said that no such action had been taken against the Mavi Marmara out of fear that the vessel might be stranded in the middle of the sea, endangering the people on board. Israel was accused of sabotaging activist ships in the past but no evidence has been found to back up these claims. Three ships – the ''Rachel Corrie'', the ''Challenger I'' and the ''Challenger II'' – suffered damage or malfunction. While the ''Challenger I'' was able to continue, the ''Challenger II'' had to turn back halfway through the journey and ''Rachel Corrie'' docked for repairs in [[Malta]]. [[Greta Berlin]] of the Free Gaza Movement said that electric wires may have been tampered with.{{Cite news |date=2 June 2010 |title=Israel releases last of activists seized on aid ships |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article444828.ece |work=The Hindu |location=Chennai, India |agency=DPA |accessdate=5 October 2011}} ==Raid and aftermath== {{main|Gaza flotilla raid}} Israeli forces [[Gaza flotilla raid#Raid|raided the flotilla]] on the night of 30–31 May 2010 in [[international waters]] of the Mediterranean Sea, boarding the ships using speedboats and helicopters. Nine activists were killed. Dozens of activists and seven Israeli soldiers were injured. [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Toys from Flotilla Unloaded at Ashdod Port.jpg|thumb|Children's toys from the Gaza flotilla are unloaded at the [[Port of Ashdod|Ashdod Port]], to be shipped to the Gaza Strip via the [[Kerem Shalom border crossing|Kerem Shalom Crossing]].]] [[Gaza flotilla raid#Conclusion of raid|After the raid]], the activists were detained in Israel pending release: all were deported by 6 June. The ships were towed to Israel and those claimed by their owners were returned. The aid was delivered to Gaza under United Nations supervision on 17 June. Widespread [[Reactions to the Gaza flotilla raid|international condemnation of and reaction to the raid]] followed. Various [[Gaza flotilla raid#Investigations|investigations]] were conducted, including by the United Nations, Israel and Turkey. [[Israel-Turkey relations]] were strained, and Israel subsequently eased its blockade on Gaza. ==Subsequent events== ===Freedom Flotilla II=== {{Main|Freedom Flotilla II}} ===Freedom Flotilla West Papua=== Another movement happen in Pacific region, On 15 August 2013, at 10 pm, two peace mission yachts of 15 Aboriginal and Papuan activists in support of the West Papuan independence struggle from Indonesian leave Cairns, Australia headed to the Merauke Town, southern region of Indonesia's Papua.{{Cite news |date=15 August 2013 |title='Freedom flotilla' Will sail to Merauke |url=http://www.en.papua.us/2013/08/freedom-flotilla-will-sail-to-merauke.html |work=Papua Untuk Semua |location=Jayapura, Indonesia |accessdate=4 September 2013}} The Australian and West Papuan activists are set to sail to territory of West Papua without permission while Indonesian military has confirmed that they will raid them if they crossing the borders. The fleet is expected to make unauthorised landfall in West Papua in September. Meanwhile, Four West Papuan pro-independence leaders were arrested by authorities on Wednesday, in Sorong - a coastal city in the western Indonesian province of West Papua - on charges of organising a congregation pray meeting at the Marantha Church in the city. Over 2000 people had gathered at the local church to pray for the safe passage of the West Papua Freedom Flotilla, around 200 policemen surrounded the church and arrested the four leaders. In show of global solidarity, a demonstration took place outside the Indonesian Embassy, in The Hague, calling for the safe passage of the Freedom Flotilla to West Papua. The campaigners have opened an office in the city in an effort to push for the cause of West Papua's independence and highlight the alleged human rights abuses that have taken place in West Papua since 1962.{{Cite news |date=31 August 2013 |title=Four West Papuan Pro-independence Leaders in Sorong Arrested for Pray to Freedom Flotilla |url=http://www.en.papua.us/2013/08/four-west-papuan-pro-independence.html |work=Papua Untuk Semua |location=Jayapura, Indonesia |accessdate=4 September 2013}} ==See also== * [[Freedom Flotilla III]] {{Use Australian English|date=March 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} The '''''Human Rights Act 2004''''' is an Act of the [[Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly]] that recognises the fundamental human rights of individuals. It was the first of its kind in [[Australia]], however Victoria has since passed the [[Victorian Charter of Human Rights and Responsibilities]] and the Human Rights Consultation is currently deliberating on whether the federal government should adopt a human rights act.
The Act established an Australian Capital Territory Human Rights Commissioner. It also empowers the [[ACT Supreme Court]] to declare on compliance of legislation.
The Act was amended in 2005 by the ''Human Rights Commission Legislation Amendment Act 2005''
==See also== * [[Bill of rights]]
==External links== * [http://www.legislation.act.gov.au/a/2004-5/default.asp Human Rights Act 2004] * [http://www.hrc.act.gov.au/index.html ACT Human Rights Office]

'''Internal sin''', in Christianity, is the idea that [[sin]] may be committed not only by outward deeds but also by the inner activity of the mind, quite apart from any external manifestation.<ref>{{citation |author=Aquinas, Thomas|title=Summa Theologiae}}</ref> [[Thought crime]]s were as old as [[heresy]], but the [[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]]'s alarms received new emphasis at the [[Council of Trent]] (Session XIV, chapter. v). The session, while reiterating that all [[mortal sin]]s must be confessed, singled out the unspoken ones that "sometimes more grievously wound the soul and are more dangerous than sins which are openly committed".<ref>{{citation |title=The Catholic Encyclopedia: An International Reference|year=1912|editor=Herbermann et al., Charles}}</ref>
Three kinds of internal sin are usually distinguished by [[Catholicism|Catholics]]: * ''delectatio morosa'', the pleasure taken in a sinful thought or imagination even without desiring it; * ''gaudium'', dwelling with complacency on sins already committed; * ''desiderium'', the desire for what is sinful.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/14004b.htm|title=Sin|publisher=New Advent|accessdate=11 May 2014}}</ref>
== Biblical quotes== * [[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]] 5:28 ''But I tell you that anyone who looks at a woman lustfully has already committed adultery with her in his heart''. * [[Epistle to the Romans|Romans]] 6:12 ''Therefore do not let sin reign in your mortal body so that you obey its evil desires''.
==See also== * [[Cathar]] * [[Inquisition]] * [[Orthodoxy]]

{{other uses|Ipso facto (disambiguation)|IPSO (disambiguation)}} {{Wiktionary}} {{Italic title}} '''{{lang|la|Ipso facto}}''' is a [[Latin]] phrase, directly translated as "by the fact itself",<ref>{{cite book|last=Dominik|first=William J.|title=Words & Ideas|year=2006|publisher=Bolchazy-Carducci|location=Wauconda, Ill.|isbn=0-86516-485-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EUlrPKNQiTMC&pg=PA163&dq=%22ipso+facto%22+latin+phrases&hl=en&sa=X&ei=kc0_T9y8MYydgQe20-ijCA&ved=0CEQQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=163}}</ref> which means that a specific phenomenon is a ''direct'' consequence, a resultant ''effect'', of the action in question, instead of being brought about by a previous action. It is a [[term of art]] used in [[philosophy]], [[law]], and [[science]]. An example in law is [[money laundering]]: the act is not {{lang|la|ipso facto}} illegal{{where|date=November 2018}}{{fact|date=November 2018}} because it is an exchange but is done as a cover for something else, so the act puts the actions of an individual in question. A common English [[idiom]] with a similar meaning is "[[wikt:in and of itself#Adverb|in and of itself]]". Compare also "by itself" and "[[wikt:per se#Adverb|per se]]".
Aside from its technical uses, it occurs frequently in literature, particularly in scholarly addenda: e.g., "Faustus had signed his life away, and was, {{lang|la|ipso facto}}, incapable of repentance" (from [[Christopher Marlowe]], ''[[The Tragical History of Dr. Faustus]]'') or "These prejudices are rooted in the idea that every tramp {{lang|la|ipso facto}} is a blackguard" (from [[George Orwell]], ''[[Down and Out in Paris and London]]'').
==In Catholic canon law== {{main|Latae sententiae}} {{lang|la|Ipso facto}} denotes the automatic character of the loss of membership in a religious body by someone guilty of a specified action.<ref>{{cite web|title=dismissal ipso facto|url=http://saints.sqpn.com/ncd02747.htm|publisher=New Catholic Dictionary|accessdate=18 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120718022301/http://saints.sqpn.com/ncd02747.htm|archivedate=18 July 2012|df=}}</ref> Within the [[canon law (Catholic Church)|canon law]] of the [[Catholic Church]], the phrase {{lang|la|[[latae sententiae]]}} is more commonly used than {{lang|la|ipso facto}} with regard to ecclesiastical penalties such as [[excommunication (Catholic Church)|excommunication]]. It indicates that the effect follows even if no verdict (in Latin, {{lang|la|sententia}}) is pronounced by an ecclesiastical superior or tribunal.
==See also== * [[List of Latin phrases]] * {{lang|la|[[Eo ipso]]}} * [[Q.E.D.]]

An '''irreparable injury''' is, in [[equity (law)|equity]], "the type of harm which no monetary compensation can cure or put conditions back the way they were." <ref>[http://dictionary.law.com/default2.asp?selected=1031&bold=%7C%7C%7C%7C Law Dictionary].</ref>
==The irreparable injury rule== It has traditionally been a requirement of [[Equity (law)|equity]] that no relief can be granted unless there is irreparable injury. This requirement, commonly called the "irreparable injury rule", has been the subject of sustained academic criticism, especially by remedies scholar [[Douglas Laycock]], who has argued at length that the rule does not actually explain the decisions of courts in the United States.<ref>Douglas Laycock, The Death of the Irreparable Injury Rule (Oxford Univ. Press 1991).</ref> Nevertheless, the irreparable injury rule was reaffirmed by the U.S. Supreme Court in [[eBay v. MercExchange]], 547 U.S. 388 (2006), a case in which the Court announced a test for injunctive relief that required, among other things, that the plaintiff prove "that it has suffered an irreparable injury".
==The concept of irreparable injury in various jurisdictions== The general idea that there are irreparable injuries has been recognized in various jurisdictions.
===United Nations=== The [[United Nations]] Staff Rules recognize the concept for the purpose of [[employment]] [[appeals]].<ref>See [https://www.un.org/jab/faqs.html U.N. Joint Appeals Board web site], citing, Law Dictionary, ''supra''.</ref>
===United States=== Virtually every [[United States|state]] recognizes the concept under [[common law]] or equity, including [[New York (state)|New York]] <ref>[http://www.cityinjurylawyer.com/glossary.html Private law firm's web site glossary].</ref> [[Oklahoma]],<ref>[http://www.oscn.net/applications/oscn/DeliverDocument.asp?CiteID=39090 Oklahoma case]</ref> [[South Dakota]],<ref>[http://www.state.sd.us/puc/commission/dockets/telecom/2006/tc06-010/confidentialityagreement.pdf S.D. Public Service Commission web site]</ref> and [[Utah]].<ref>[http://www.attygen.state.ut.us/legalglossary.html Attorney General of Utah web site]</ref>
In addition to state law, the [[Federal government]] takes note of the purpose of an '''injunction''' as being to "prevent irreparable damage or injury".<ref>[http://www.azd.uscourts.gov/azd/courtinfo.nsf/court/files/$file/glossary+of+terms.pdf D.Ariz. official web site].</ref><ref>[http://www.txnd.uscourts.gov/publications/glossary.html N.D.Tex. official web site]</ref><ref>[http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/eousa/kidspage/glossary.html DOJ Web site, Kid's page].</ref>
===Africa=== The East Africa Court of Justice has noted the concept in enjoining an [[election]] in [[Kenya]].<ref>[http://www.eac.int/news_2006_11__EACJ_ruling_on_kenya_EALA_mps.pdf EAC web page].</ref>
===Philippines=== [[Philippines]] law notes the phrase in [[employment law]],<ref>[http://www.dole.gov.ph/faq/details.asp?id=F0000254 DOLE FAQs: Details<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>See case on [http://www.supremecourt.gov.ph/jurisprudence/1996/nov1996/110494.htm Philippines Supreme Court official web site].</ref><ref>[http://lawphil.net/judjuris/juri2002/jul2002/gr_143215_2002.html Philippine Jurisprudence web site]</ref> in a report regarding [[indigenous peoples]],<ref>See an Order on the [http://www.ncip.gov.ph/mandate/policies.php?act=dl&file=QURNSU5JU1RSQVRJVkUgQ0lSQ1VMQVIgTk8uIDEsIFMuIDIwMDMucGRm - National Commission on Indigenous Peoples web page].</ref> as well as in [[agrarian reform]].<ref>[http://www.nenepimentel.org/cgi-bin/build.pl?section=legislation;id=SBN-1567 Sen. Pimental's web site]</ref>
==See also== *[[Equity (law)]] *[[Injunction]] *[[Preliminary injunction]] *[[Temporary restraining order]] *''[[Quia timet]]''
==References== <references/>

{{Civil procedure (United States)}}
In law, a '''joinder''' is the joining of two or more legal issues together. Procedurally, a joinder allows multiple issues to be heard in one [[hearing (law)|hearing]] or [[trial]] and is done when the issues or parties involved overlap sufficiently to make the process more efficient or more fair. It helps courts avoid hearing the same facts multiple times or seeing the same parties return to court separately for each of their legal disputes. The term is also used in the realm of contracts to describe the joining of new parties to an existing agreement.
==Criminal procedure== Joinder in [[criminal law]] refers to the inclusion of additional counts or additional [[defendants]] on an [[indictment]]. In [[English law]], [[indictment|charges]] for any [[offence (law)|offence]] may be joined in the same indictment if those charges are founded on the same facts or form or are a part of a series of offences of the same or a similar nature. A number of defendants may be joined in the same [[indictment]] even if no single count applies to all of them if the counts are sufficiently linked. The [[judge]] retains the option to order separate trials.
==Civil procedure== Joinder in [[civil law (common law)|civil law]] falls under two categories: joinder of claims and joinder of parties.
===Joinder of claims=== Joinder of claims refers to bringing several legal claims against the same party together. In U.S. federal law, joinder of claims is governed by Rule 18 of the [[Federal Rules of Civil Procedure]]. These rules allow claimants to consolidate all claims that they have against an individual who is already a party to the case. Claimants may bring new claims even if these new claims are not related to the claims already stated; for example, a [[plaintiff]] suing someone for [[breach of contract]] may also sue the same person for assault. The claims may be unrelated, but they may be joined if the plaintiff desires.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rule 18. Joinder of Claims|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/rules/frcp/rule_18|publisher=Legal Information Institute|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref>
Joinder of claims requires that the court have jurisdiction over the subject matter of each of the new claims, and that joinder of claims is never compulsory. A party who sues for breach of contract can bring his suit for assault at a later date if he chooses. However, if the claims are related to the same set of facts, the plaintiff may be barred from bringing claims later by the doctrine of [[res judicata]], e.g. if a plaintiff sues for [[assault]] and the case is concluded, he may not later sue for [[Battery (tort)|battery]] regarding the same occurrence.
===Joinder of parties=== Joinder of parties also falls into two categories: [[permissive joinder]] and [[compulsory joinder]].
Federal Rule of Civil Procedure No. 20 addresses permissive joinder. Permissive joinder allows multiple plaintiffs to join in an action if each of their claims arise from the same transaction or occurrence, and if there is a common question of law or fact relating to all plaintiffs' claims. For example, several landowners may join together in suing a factory for environmental runoff onto their property. Permissive joinder is also appropriate to join multiple defendants, as long as the same considerations as for joining multiple plaintiffs are met. This often occurs in lawsuits regarding faulty products; the plaintiff will sue the manufacturer of the final product and the manufacturers of any constituent parts. The court must have personal jurisdiction over every defendant joined in the action.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rule 20. Permissive Joinder of Parties|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/rules/frcp/rule_20|publisher=Legal Information Institute|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref>
Compulsory joinder is governed by Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 19, which makes it mandatory that some parties be joined. Parties that must be joined are those necessary and indispensable to the litigation. The rule includes several reasons why this might be true, including if that party has an interest in the dispute that they will be unable to protect if they are not joined. For example, if three parties each lay claim to a piece of property and the first two sue each other, the third will not be able to protect his (alleged) interest in the property if he is not joined. Another circumstance is when a party might end up with inconsistent obligations, for example he may be required by two different courts to grant two different parties exclusive rights to the same piece of property. This is avoided by joining the parties in one lawsuit. However, while "necessary" parties must be joined if that joinder is possible, the litigation will continue without them if joinder is impossible, for example, if the court does not have jurisdiction over the party. By contrast, if [[indispensable party|"indispensable" parties]] cannot be joined, the litigation cannot go forward. Courts have some discretion in determining what parties are indispensable, though the Federal Rules provide some guidelines.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rule 19. Required Joinder of Parties|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/rules/frcp/rule_19|publisher=Legal Information Institute|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref>
===Timing=== Rules 18 and 20 have different effects depending on when they are invoked. Joinder may occur as part of an original pleading. There is a discretionary period after the initial filing, during which original pleadings may be amended as a matter of course. Parties or claims or both may be joined during this time. However, if the time for modifying the pleadings has passed, the pleading can be amended with the permission of the opposing party or the judge, though this permission is frequently granted. Rule 15 describes the process for amending a claim.
Under Rule 42 of Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, the court, if actions involve a common question of law or fact, may join any or all issues, consolidate the actions or issue any other orders to avoid unnecessary cost or delay. The court may also order a separate trial of one or more separate issues or claims for convenience, to avoid prejudice, or to expedite or improve economy.
==Contract law== Joinder agreements are commonly used in [[mergers and acquisitions]] to bind individual shareholders to the terms of an existing merger agreement<ref>{{cite web|title=Contribution and Joinder Agreements|url=https://www.srsacquiom.com/contribution-and-joinder-agreements/|publisher=SRS Acquiom|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> or shareholder agreement,<ref>{{cite web|title=LLC Agreement (Joinder Agreement)|url=http://us.practicallaw.com/8-383-6673?q=&qp=&qo=&qe=|publisher=Practical Law|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref> and in [[trust (law)|trust]] practice to bind a donor to the terms and conditions of the trust.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Legal terminology]] [[Category:Civil procedure]]

'''Keyser's Pills''' were an 18th century patent medicine containing mercuric oxide and [[acetic acid]] used to treat [[syphilis]].
[[Mercury (element)|Mercury]] was a [[History_of_syphilis#Historical_treatments|common, long-standing treatment for syphilis]]. Keyser's pills were marketed by and named for Jean Keyser, a surgeon in the French military.<ref name="keyser1">Louis-Courvoisier M (2007)[http://www.jameslindlibrary.org/articles/an-18th-century-controlled-trial-prompted-by-a-potential-shortage-of-hospital-beds/ An 18th century controlled trial prompted by a potential shortage of hospital beds.], JLL Bulletin: Commentaries on the history of treatment evaluation</ref> They were a standard treatment in the French military by the 1750s.<ref name="pox">Conner, Susan P. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Lp7rsfCI5MAC&pg=PA15#v=onepage&q&f=false The Pox in Eighteenth-Century France], in ''The Secret Malady: Venereal Disease in Eighteenth-century Britain and France'', p. 25</ref> Keyser's solution of mercury mixed with acetic acid was intended to reduce the side-effects of mercury treatments, but still proved quite dangerous. A trial of four women at [[Bicêtre Hospital]] caused colic, diarrhea, fevers, nausea and vomiting, and [[mouth ulcers]] to the level of [[gangrene]]. One subject [[miscarried]].<ref name="pox"/>
A clinical trial of the pills was performed in Geneva in 1761 and deemed successful, which led the pills to be a considered a good treatment for some time, though not without continuing controversy and debate.<ref name="keyser1"/><ref name="watchman">(1 September 1834). [https://books.google.com/books?id=ycIhAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA144&lpg=PA144#v=onepage&q&f=false The Vienna or Dutch Pills], ''Botanic Watchman'' ([[Albany, New York]]), p. 144</ref><ref name="answer">[https://books.google.com/books?id=rHlPAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA163&lpg=PA163#v=onepage&q&f=false Art. 26], ''The Monthly Review'', p. 163 (1766).</ref> English physician [[John Pringle (physician)|John Pringe]] cautioned biographer [[James Boswell]] against taking the pills, as well as Kennedy's Lisbon Diet Drink, for his veneral disease.<Ref name="pringle">[https://books.google.com/books?id=ORyJr1P7uGgC&pg=PA628&lpg=PA628#v=onepage&q&f=false The Oxford Illustrated Companion to Medicine], p. 628 (3d ed. 2001)</ref> [[Simon-Nicholas Henri Linguet]]'s French novel ''La Cacomonade'' also referenced the "[[dragée]]s de Keyser".<ref name="intl">Fournier. [https://books.google.com/books?id=GfkgAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA165#v=onepage&q&f=false Treatment of Syphllis]], ''International Medical Magazine'' (March 1892)</ref>
The pill were also marketed in the American colonies in the 1760s and 1770s.<ref name="marketplace">Breen, T.H. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Skum_IkNN5gC&pg=PT86#v=onepage&q&f=false The Marketplace of Revolution: How Consumer Politics Shaped American Independence] (2004)</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
